summary: This document is a compilation of news articles from August 13-14, 2019, primarily focused on the aftermath of Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody. It includes victim testimony from Jennifer Araoz, details of the jail security failures, political reactions, and coverage of other unrelated federal cases in the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the case; found dead in his jail cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019, while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges.

persons.name: Jennifer Araoz
persons.context: Publicly accused Epstein of raping her when she was 15 in 2001-2002; filed a civil action under New York's Child Victims Act.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.context: Oversaw investigations into Epstein's death; promised to bring co-conspirators to justice; ordered reviews of jail security failures.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.context: Urged Attorney General Barr to rip up Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution agreement and demanded answers on the circumstances of Epstein's suicide.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Frequently described as Epstein's former girlfriend and alleged procurer of underage victims; subject of increased scrutiny after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.role: Former U.S. Attorney for SD Florida, former Labor Secretary
persons.context: Negotiated the controversial 2008 non-prosecution agreement with Epstein, which led to his resignation from the Trump cabinet.

persons.name: Lamine N'Diaye
persons.context: Warden of the MCC where Epstein died; was temporarily reassigned pending investigation.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Vowed to continue the investigation into Epstein and his co-conspirators after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.role: Jeffrey Epstein's brother, real estate investor
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein's younger brother; offered his Florida home for bond; business ties between his company and Jeffrey's were noted.

persons.name: Scott Borgerson
persons.role: Tech CEO, reported boyfriend of Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Reported to be in a relationship with Ghislaine Maxwell and living with her in a Massachusetts mansion.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.context: Epstein's MC2 modeling agency business partner; an alleged victim claimed she was forced to have sex with him.

persons.name: Nadia Marcinkova
persons.context: Operated a business registered at a building owned by Mark Epstein; identified as a potential co-conspirator.

persons.name: Sarah Kellen
persons.context: Operated a business registered at a building owned by Mark Epstein; identified as a potential co-conspirator.

persons.name: Ehud Barak
persons.context: Reported to have regularly spent time at a condominium owned by Mark Epstein.

persons.name: Leslie Wexner
persons.context: Epstein managed his assets through J. Epstein & Co.; Mark Epstein purchased a building from him.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Florida attorney representing a number of Epstein's alleged victims; commented on models housed in Mark Epstein's building.

persons.name: Ben Sprecher
persons.context: Arrested on federal child pornography charges unrelated to the Epstein case; featured in the news digest.

persons.name: Faheem Walter
persons.context: Sentenced for his role in a restaurant shooting; case covered in the news digest.

persons.name: Joel Margulies
persons.context: Convicted of fraud related to a snack and pet food investment scheme; case covered in the news digest.

persons.name: Greg Craig
persons.role: Former Obama White House Counsel, defendant
persons.context: Faced trial for allegedly lying to federal investigators about work for Ukraine; his trial was postponed.

persons.name: Steven Donziger
persons.context: Facing criminal contempt prosecution related to a lawsuit against Chevron; case covered in the news digest.

connections.description: Maxwell is repeatedly described as Epstein's former girlfriend, closest pal, and alleged procurer of underage victims for his sex trafficking ring.
Araoz alleges Epstein raped her when she was 15 after a recruiter approached her for him, and she visited his home for over a year.
Mark is Jeffrey Epstein's younger brother; offered his home for bond and there are documented business connections between their companies.
Reported to be in a relationship and living together in a secluded Massachusetts mansion.
As U.S. Attorney, Acosta negotiated the 2008 non-prosecution agreement that allowed Epstein to plead guilty to state charges.
Brunel was Epstein's partner in the MC2 modeling agency; an alleged victim claimed she was forced to have sex with him.
Mark Epstein purchased a condominium building from Wexner in the early 1990s.

events.title: Araoz meets Epstein
events.description: Jennifer Araoz, then 14, is approached by a recruiter for Jeffrey Epstein and begins visiting his Upper East Side mansion.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta negotiates a deal where Epstein pleads guilty to state charges, serving 13 months, and receives immunity for himself and potential co-conspirators from federal charges in Florida.

events.title: Epstein Arrest in New York
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is arrested on federal sex trafficking charges in New York.

events.title: Epstein First Suicide Attempt
events.description: Epstein is placed on suicide watch after an apparent attempt in his jail cell.

events.title: Epstein Found Dead in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center at 6:30 a.m., an apparent suicide by hanging.

events.title: Jail Guards Placed on Leave
events.description: Two guards assigned to watch Epstein are placed on administrative leave for allegedly falling asleep and falsifying log entries about checking on him.

events.title: Araoz Files Civil Lawsuit
events.description: Jennifer Araoz files a civil action against Jeffrey Epstein's estate and accomplices under New York's Child Victims Act.

locations: 301 East 66th Street, New York (building owned by Mark Epstein)
keyFacts: Jennifer Araoz provides a detailed, first-person account of being recruited at age 14 and sexually assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein over a period of more than a year, starting in 2001.
Two guards at the Metropolitan Correctional Center allegedly fell asleep and falsified logs, failing to check on Epstein for about three hours before he was found dead.
Senator Ben Sasse urges Attorney General Barr to 'rip up' the 2008 non-prosecution agreement to allow prosecution of Epstein's co-conspirators.
Ghislaine Maxwell is reported to be living in seclusion with tech CEO Scott Borgerson in a $3 million oceanfront mansion in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Massachusetts.

Business connections are highlighted between Jeffrey Epstein's company and his brother Mark's real estate firm, Ossa Properties, including shared asset managers and the housing of Epstein associates in Mark's building.
